Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story:
The shrill ring of my phone cut through the hum of the workshop. “Sensor errors again,” my supervisor barked, “Production’s down. We need you now.” I glanced at the clock—just an hour before Mincha at the synagogue. My toolbox felt heavier than usual as I weighed my options. The plant’s main unit had already been idle for thirty minutes, and I knew every minute cost the company dearly. My hands itched to get to work, to diagnose the fault, to prove—once again—that I was the one who could fix what no one else could.

But my kippah pressed against my scalp, a gentle reminder of my other world. The rabbi always said our presence at services mattered, that each voice added to the prayers. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t let work pull me away from my faith, not again. Yet, the expectation to be the reliable repairer tugged at me, just as the call to prayer did. My mind spun with the pressure—who would I let down this time?
